Award.AwardTitle: A Study of the Air-Water Interfacial Behavior of Biodegradable Polyesters: Toward Rational Design of a Polymeric Lung Surfactant

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration: Deficiency of lung surfactant causes a disease called respiratory distress syndrome. The standard treatment of this disease involves an injection of animal-extracted, lipid-based surfactant formulation into the patient?s lung. However, the treatment if very expensive and there has been a long-standing search for a more viable (synthetic) formulation. This proposal will probe (using optical micro-viscosimetry and micro-rheology techniques) the molecular origins of the minimum surface tension exhibited by promising biodegradable polyesters (PLGA) , the surface pressure-area hysteresis behavior in dynamically compressed films, and the viscoelastic properties of PLGA monolayers. If successful, the results of this proposed research can have an important impact on the field of materials engineering, expanding our fundamental understanding of materials properties and dynamics of thin film polymers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The present NSF grant (CBET-1264336, 8/2013 – 7/2016, titled “A Study of the Air-Water Interfacial Behavior of Biodegradable Polyesters”) has enabled us to test a wide range of polymers for use in treatment of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Currently, the standard treatment for RDS involves injection of an exogenous lipid-based surfactant formulation into the patient’s lung. Treatments based on these exogenous surfactants are, however, very expensive. Recently, our laboratory has developed promising polymer lung surfactant materials that have the potential to significantly lower the overall cost of RDS treatment than current RDS therapeutics and thus make this treatment method available more widely.

Currently, the main source of treatment for RDS is natural lung surfactants derived from animals. The major drawback of animal derived treatment is that the harvesting process is costly and carries the risk of pathogenic contamination. Also, these conventional lung surfactants (containing proteins susceptible to denaturation) require sophisticated delivery procedures (endotracheal instillation) that can only be practiced in locations where skilled physicians and advanced care facilities are available. Synthetic polymer lung surfactants can solve these problems. Synthetic polymers can be mass produced and formulated at low cost. Also, unlike natural lung surfactants which rely on proteins for proper functioning, polymer lung surfactants function regardless of their molecular conformation, and are thus more suitable for aerosol delivery. Polymer lung surfactants thus enable development of a more cost effective treatment that can be made available to low-resource countries where RDS remains a significant contributor to neonatal mortality rates.

Through this project, the graduate and undergraduate students involved have developed research skills and knowledge covering the studies of polymer science and bioengineering. This project has also provided research training for talented high school students. A patent application has been filed on the technology developed as a result of this study. In order to validate the commercial potential of this technology, the PI and its entrepreneurial partners now plan to conduct an NSF I-Corps “market validation” project in early 2017.
